articles.headline: Elon Musk Is Spreading Election Misinformation, but X’s Fact Checkers Are Long Gone
articles.snippet: Civil rights lawyers and Democrats are sounding alarms about Mr. Musk’s claims about voting. The Biden campaign called his posts “profoundly irresponsible.”
articles.abstract: Civil rights lawyers and Democrats are sounding alarms about Mr. Musk’s claims about voting. The Biden campaign called his posts “profoundly irresponsible.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2020, when President Donald J. Trump wrote messages on Twitter warning that increased reliance on mail-in ballots would lead to a “rigged election,” the platform ran a corrective, debunking his claims.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Kate Conger

articles.headline: Federal Trade Commission Launches Inquiry Into A.I. Deals by Tech Giants
articles.snippet: The agency plans to scrutinize Microsoft, Amazon and Google for their investments in the A.I. start-ups OpenAI and Anthropic.
articles.abstract: The agency plans to scrutinize Microsoft, Amazon and Google for their investments in the A.I. start-ups OpenAI and Anthropic.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission opened an inquiry on Thursday into the multibillion-dollar investments by Microsoft, Amazon and Google in the artificial intelligence start-ups OpenAI and Anthropic, broadening the regulator’s efforts to corral the power the tech giants can have over A.I.

articles.headline: Navarro Is Sentenced to 4 Months in Prison for Stonewalling Congress
articles.snippet: Peter Navarro was found guilty in September of criminal contempt of Congress, making him the second Trump aide to face penalties related to one of the chief investigations into Jan. 6.
articles.abstract: Peter Navarro was found guilty in September of criminal contempt of Congress, making him the second Trump aide to face penalties related to one of the chief investigations into Jan. 6.
articles.lead_paragraph: Peter Navarro, a trade adviser to former President Donald J. Trump who helped lay plans to keep Mr. Trump in office after the 2020 election, was sentenced on Thursday to four months in prison for defying a subpoena from the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.

articles.headline: Apple Overhauls App Store in Europe, in Response to New Digital Law
articles.snippet: An E.U. law taking effect in March forced Apple to loosen its grip on the App Store, changes it had long resisted.
articles.abstract: An E.U. law taking effect in March forced Apple to loosen its grip on the App Store, changes it had long resisted.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Apple introduced the App Store in 2008, it has tightly controlled the apps and services allowed on iPhones and iPads, giving the company an iron grip on one of the digital economy’s most valuable storefronts.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Tripp Mickle

articles.headline: Inside Trump’s Cutthroat Conquest of Iowa and New Hampshire
articles.snippet: The former president’s victories in Iowa and New Hampshire were the product of a win-or-else ethos, a fractured opposition and his power to make the party stand for whatever he stands for.
articles.abstract: The former president’s victories in Iowa and New Hampshire were the product of a win-or-else ethos, a fractured opposition and his power to make the party stand for whatever he stands for.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s campaign couldn’t have scripted the results in Iowa any better.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Cruise Says Hostility to Regulators Led to Grounding of Its Autonomous Cars
articles.snippet: A law firm’s review found that executives had failed to fully explain an October crash, which the Justice Department is also investigating.
articles.abstract: A law firm’s review found that executives had failed to fully explain an October crash, which the Justice Department is also investigating.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cruise, the driverless car subsidiary of General Motors, said in a report on Thursday that an adversarial approach taken by its top executives toward regulators had led to a cascade of events that ended with a nationwide suspension of Cruise’s fleet and investigations by California and federal authorities, including the Justice Department.
articles.byline: By Tripp Mickle and Cade Metz

articles.headline: Trump Strengthens Grip on Capitol Hill as He Presses Toward Nomination
articles.snippet: The former president’s opposition has all but killed the prospects for a bipartisan border deal, reflecting how his influence in Congress has grown as he gains ground in the Republican primary.
articles.abstract: The former president’s opposition has all but killed the prospects for a bipartisan border deal, reflecting how his influence in Congress has grown as he gains ground in the Republican primary.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, Senate Republicans have been working with Democrats on a deal they have described as a once-in-a-generation opportunity for a conservative border security bill, and for weeks, they have hinted that they are tantalizingly close to an agreement.

articles.headline: U.S., Sensing Opportunity, Makes New Push for Gaza Cease-Fire
articles.snippet: William Burns, the C.I.A. director, planned to meet Israeli, Egyptian and Qatari officials in Europe to try to secure a deal to release the Hamas hostages and a pause in the combat.
articles.abstract: William Burns, the C.I.A. director, planned to meet Israeli, Egyptian and Qatari officials in Europe to try to secure a deal to release the Hamas hostages and a pause in the combat.
articles.lead_paragraph: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. director, plans to travel to Europe to meet with senior Israeli, Egyptian and Qatari officials, in a sign the United States is pushing to secure a deal to release the hostages being held in the Gaza Strip and broker a prolonged cease-fire, according to U.S. officials.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Hiba Yazbek, Aaron Boxerman and Roni Caryn Rabin

articles.headline: As China’s Markets Stumble, Japan Rises Toward Record
articles.snippet: A change in perception among investors about China and Japan is one of the biggest themes in the markets right now.
articles.abstract: A change in perception among investors about China and Japan is one of the biggest themes in the markets right now.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s a shift underway in Asia that’s reverberating through global financial markets.
articles.byline: By Joe Rennison and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Is Cryptocurrency Like Stocks and Bonds? Courts Move Closer to an Answer.
articles.snippet: Federal judges are weighing whether digital currencies should be subject to the same rules as stocks and bonds. The outcome could shape crypto’s future in the U.S.
articles.abstract: Federal judges are weighing whether digital currencies should be subject to the same rules as stocks and bonds. The outcome could shape crypto’s future in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, the pioneers of the cryptocurrency industry envisioned digital coins as an alternate branch of finance, a renegade sector that would operate outside the reach of big banks and government regulators.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: A Child of Another War Who Makes Music for Ukrainians
articles.snippet: Mirza Ramic, a Bosnian who sought refuge in the United States, is bringing his electronic music to Ukraine, “to show my support in these hard times.”
articles.abstract: Mirza Ramic, a Bosnian who sought refuge in the United States, is bringing his electronic music to Ukraine, “to show my support in these hard times.”
articles.lead_paragraph: When the owner of an underground club in Kyiv reached out to Western musicians to play in Ukraine, long before the war, there were not so many takers.

articles.headline: Economists Predicted a Recession. So Far They’ve Been Wrong.
articles.snippet: A widely predicted recession never showed up. Now, economists are assessing what the unexpected resilience tells us about the future.
articles.abstract: A widely predicted recession never showed up. Now, economists are assessing what the unexpected resilience tells us about the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: The recession America was expecting never showed up.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
